The waiting part of all of this is the most difficult part of any of it. I would probably see if I could push for an earlier appointment; I'd struggle to wait that long for answers. Regardless, post as often as you need to. We're all right here! Lynn

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2013 04:15AM LibraryLynn wrote: Thanks! Surgery day went well and nodes and margins were clear! You will do great on Tuesday, LK! Lynn
Posts.Title: Frozen with Fear LKSHER Ariom

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2013 02:01PM LibraryLynn wrote: I was diagnosed on 2/13 with grade 1 IDC. I am having a lumpectomy tomorrow, as well as a sentinel node biopsy. I am just 50 with no children. I know what you are feeling, and I have found my co-workers and friends have been amazing, especially the ones who are survivors. When I feel really terrified, I go and find one of them. It's good to have some "living" proof right there in front of me. Coming here also helps. This is an amazingly supportive group of women, and they have calmed and validated my feelings more than once. Feel free to message me, if you want to "talk". I am not a fountain of knowledge, but I will be happy to listen. I am all too acquainted with the tears that come out of the blue. I am a librarian at a high school, and the acapella group sang to me at a sports assembly last Friday (it was my birthday), and I blubbered my way through the entire day. It's okay...let people support you. I'll let you know how surgery goes tomorrow! Wish me luck because we're supposed to get a snowpocalypse tonight in to tomorrow, as well. Why can't anything just be easy? :)
Posts.Title: Frozen with Fear LKSHER Ariom

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2013 12:12AM LibraryLynn wrote: It's very understandable to be frustrated and anxious. We certainly understand both of those feelings here on this board!  Don't overthink it, 2super. I know, I know...way easier said than done. And I second the not to Dr. Google what little you do know now. You will only give yourself extra stress. None of us need that. Get that mammo/us appointment and then put it out of your mind. Odds are definitely in your favor that it will be nothing of great concern. This is am amazingly supportive group of people here, so feel free to hop on and vent or just say hi when you can't sleep in the middle of the night. You have found an excellent place to learn and feel cared for. Lynn
Posts.Title: Questions regarding doc visit 2superboyz

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2013 04:25PM LibraryLynn wrote: I would like to join in here. Taking care of you is the absolute best plan! Do whatever you do that takes your mind off things, and do your best not to stew (easier said than done, I know).  I kept telling myself that it is what it is, and all the fretting in the world won't change it.  And I applaud you for acknowledging that it's okay to feel scared. Once I figured that out and expressed my anxiety to health care people, I was treated like a queen. I told them that I can't be a brave soldier right now because this is scary, and they agreed and took excellent care of me!  This is the perfect place to vent/scream/cry/rail at the world because every single one of us here has been right there. We've got your back (and your front), and this is an amazingly supportive group!  Let us know how you're doing. Lynn

It seems you see so many negative things about it, it's nice to read some of the lesser evils. I want those evil cancer specks zapped, but I have very sensitive skin, and I'm concerned. It's good to read your issues and feel your support. Thanks! Lynn

It is scary and overwhelming and just downright difficult sometimes, but I feel like I can do anything with so much genuine support and caring. Thank you all. I have surgery in a week (lumpectomy and nodes), and your words of kindness will ring in my ears.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed LibraryLynn Kalonis52

Posts.Content: LibraryLynn wrote: I was diagnosed with grade 1 invasive ductal carcinoma on Wednesday. The tumor was 2.5mm, as measure by the ultrasound. I had a core needle biopsy on Tuesday, and I spoke to the surgeon and decided on a lumpectomy, sentinal node biopsy and radiation for six weeks, five times a week. I will be 50 in two weeks. I'm scared, but I feel a great deal of love and support. I know I am very lucky to have that. I live and work in a small town in Wisconsin, and my surgeon is someone that I have known and respected for thirty years. We are doing surgery on March 5th, after he returns from a mission trip to Haiti. I just wanted to introduce myself because I know I'm going to have questions and need support here from people who have been through this. I am trying not to be scared and not to be terrified. Sometimes I lose that fight. I feel like I need to be strong for others, and I know that's wrong, but I want us all to remain positive and confident. It's difficult. Dx 2/13/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 3/4/2013 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed LibraryLynn Kalonis52

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2013 09:32AM LibraryLynn wrote: From your neighbor to the east, Wisconsin sends up a YAYAY for B9!!!  I'm doing the happy dance but not moving around too much as my SNB surgery hurts under my arm. :) Lynn
Posts.Title: Stressing about surgical biopsy SueInMN LibraryLynn

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 01:52AM LibraryLynn wrote: LMB, Welcome. I am story that your here and scared, but we all know exactly what you are feeling. This is an exceptionally supportive group of people. The only surefire way to rule out cancer its to do a biopsy. If that is not done, the question remains. Odds are in your favor as 80% of biopsies are benign. I received my news the following day but that varies by provider. There is nothing the radiologist can tel you for certain without the biopsy. Go for your biopsy and do the best that you can to breathe and take care of yourself. Don't research Dr. Google because you will just scare yourself. Talk to a friend or close family member and acknowledgethat you are scared. This is, by far, the most difficult nerve-wracking time. I told everyone; that is counter to what a lot of people do but I needed the support. Do not hesitate to private message me or come to the board with your questions our feelings. Believe me, e wish we didn't but we so get it. Let us know what you learn and how you did. I'm sending healing thoughts your way!
Posts.Title: Pending Biopsy - Scared LMB71203 LMB71203

Posts.Content: LibraryLynn wrote: I have used hypnosis in the past, and it has helped me with a severe phobia and a surgery that I had in 1994. This time around, I was not able to afford to see a provider, so I did the next best thing. I found an audio that I would like to now recommend to anyone who is having any type of surgery. I obtained my copy on Audible.com. I don't know if it's available elsewhere.  It is called Preparing for Surgery: Hypnosis for Comfort and Healing. The narrator and author is an EMT named Maggie Staiger. It is about 15 minutes long. At first, I didn't know how I felt about her voice, but I quickly found comfort in it. I listened to it every night for the past two weeks as I was drifting off to sleep. I often fell asleep before it was half over, but that doesn't matter with hypnosis. In fact, I think it works better that way. I also listened to it at the hospital today to calm myself.  If anyone has any questions about it, feel free to PM me. I really think it helped me a great deal! Gentle hugs and healing white light to all. Lynn Dx 2/13/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage IB, Grade 1, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 3/4/2013 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Subliminal Surgical Audio LibraryLynn exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 08:09PM LibraryLynn wrote: Hello all! I'm new here. I was diagnosed 2/13/13, and I had my lumpectomy and SNB on 3/5. My recovery is going great, and there was nothing in my nodes with the preliminary test. I was one of the lucky ones who found the speck, and I like to refer to it, in a routine mammogram. It's been a whirlwind six weeks, but I have to say, my journey would have been much more difficult without the kindness and encouragement of people here! I found this site right after I was diagnosed, and it has been a godsend. I will be doing radiation down the road and probably Tamoxifen. I have to say that I am thankful the surgery is over and I can cross that hurdle off the list.  This is a great place, and I appreciate everyone here! Thanks for being so amazing, especially to frightened newbies who need your support the most. Lynn

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 08:22PM LibraryLynn wrote: Of course you're anxious, but it is good to get it checked out. As Openheart said, information is power. And sharing you concerns with your friends and family and us here is a good way to take care of yourself. Talking is powerful medicine. Come here to ask any questions you might have. This is an amazing group of people who have been through it all and understand. Take care of yourself. As it was said earlier, odds are definitely in your favor, so don't let your brain chatter scare you. We are all right here for you.

Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 08:40PM LibraryLynn wrote: I'm sure your family and friends are trying to reassure both you and themselves. They're anxious, just like you are. They will numb you for the biopsy, so you won't feel it. I had a great radiologist who respected that I was anxious, so express your concerns to him or her. They will take a few pieces of the area of concern, and this will tell you definitively what you have going on. That is great because there will not be any guessing involved, and you will know what it is. If you or your mom have any questions, please ask them here. Someone here will be able to help. This is a difficult and emotional time, sweetie. Respect that and take care of Yourself. Lynn
Posts.Title: Very scared, possibly having a biopsy. 17yearoldgirl itsjustme10

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 09:50PM LibraryLynn wrote: I am sorry you are going through this, but you have found an amazing group of people here. I came here the day I was diagnosed, and I have felt supported and cared for. You're in the best place for that and for information. As my grandma said, don't borrow trouble. It is difficult not to be freaked out, but the only way to get a definitive answer is to biopsy. Express your anxiety to the radiologist who is doing your biopsy. And don't do any internet research because it will just scare you. We are here for you, and we understand exactly what you are feeling. Lean on us and ask any questions or just come to vent. Lynn
Posts.Title: biopsy kdat1661 debmc1958

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 11:05PM LibraryLynn wrote: Didn't make the list for today on here, but I had a lumpectomy and SNB. Hubby and I made it through the snowstorm there and back (and only a minor amount of bickering in the car about him driving like Danica Patrick on the slippery roads). I was absolutely terrified of the sentinel prep and wire location. I had the kindest most wonderful radiologist (a woman), and I didn't feel a poke or pinch! I had such a bad biopsy experience that I was very frightened, but it went like clockwork. My surgery was delayed due to a bit of a back-up with the surgeon, and I won't lie...the lengthy wait was hard on me. I went in at 2:15 and was eating jello by 5:00! And I hate Jello! :) My node was clear! Those were the words the surgeon said as I came out of anesthesia, and they were the best words ever.  I want to say thank you to everyone here for being so amazing and getting me through this part of the journey. I felt the support and caring all the way in Wisconsin! I only hope I can provide that for others in the future here.  I go for a follow-up next Thursday, and we'll outline the radiation and Tamoxifen plans! Soft gentle hugs to all who had surgery recently, and a brilliant healing white light to everyone who is here! Every one of you is an amazing person!  Lynn
